cell.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Berths can be definitely engaged beforehand. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles, Gibraltar, Plymouth and London are Intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Monday. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamer leaves Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before.
The express steamer usually reaches Brindisi on Wednesday afternoon, the special train starting at 8 p.m. and arriving in London at the very convenient hour of 4.56 p.m. on Friday.
The combined Sea and special train fare is £22.9.11 Port Said to London via Brindisi or via Marseilles.
Passengers having paid fall fare in one direction are allowed an abatement of 25 per cent, on returning within 12 months.
In addition to the above regular weekly service there are sailings about twice a fortnight of 5,000 to 7,000 tons steamers to London, calling at Malta or Marseilles.
TO THE EAST.

The Mail Steamers leave Suez for Aden and Bombay every Wednesday, and for Australia and China every alternate Wednesday. A steamer leaves for Calcutta, fortnightly, and another for Japan. Passengers can embark at Port Said.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: FAST BRITISH PASSENGER STEAMERS
GREECE - TURKEY LINE.
Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.
PALESTINE - SYRIA LINE.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).
RED SEA LINE.

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: Austrian Lloyd's Steam Navigation
div.p: Alexandria-Brindisi-Trieste (Venice).

Weekly Express Mail Service. Steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m. arrive at Brindisi, Tuesday 5 a.m. in time for express to Milan, Lucerne, Paris, Vienna, Berlin, and London, leaving Brindisi 7 a.m. Arrival Trieste Wednesday about 11 a.m. in connection with Train de Luxe Trieste-Vienna-Ostende. Passengers reach London every Friday 4.50 p.m.
Fortnightly Service: Alexandria-Brindisi & Trieste Line.
Steamer leaves Alexandria on or about 10 and 24 October, 7 and 21 November, 5 and 19 December.
Syrian-Cyprus-Caramanian Line.
Steamer leaves Alexandria on or about 8 and 22 October, 5 and 19 November, 3, 17 and 31 December.

To Suez, Aden, Karachi and Bombay about 13 Nov., 1 Dec (Winter Line).
East African Line.

div.head: THE NATIONAL HOTEL, Cairo
div.p: One of the finest and most up-to-date Hotels in the Metropolis. Situated in Sharia Soliman Pasha, the very centre of the healthiest and most fashionable quarter. Stands in its own grounds with garden and lawn tennis grounds at back. Over 350 rooms and 5 saloons. Magnificent salle à manger. Handsome covered promenade verandah, 80 yards long. Highest class cuisine, electric light throughout, and lifts. English comforts. Rooms and apartments at prices to suit everyone. For further particulars apply to GENERAL MANAGER, Cairo.

div.head: GRAND HOTEL KHARTOUM, SUDAN
div.p: SUDAN.
First Class. Open all the year round.
THOROUGHLY RENOVATED AND IMPROVED.

Standing in a magnificent position in its own extensive grounds on the banks of the Blue Nile. Perfect climate, no mosquitoes, moder comfort, very homely. Concerts twice a week on the verandah of the Hotel.
ENTIRELY NEW MANAGEMENT.
For accommodation please write or wire beforehand to Manager
G. OTTO BOCK, Manager.
Lake Holland House, New York.

Hotel des Bains.- Most comfortable hotel, opposite the Baths. Pension from P.T. 40. Attached to the above hotels and specially reserved for their clients are the Golf Links (18 holes) with English Professional. Own Golf House in the dessert.
Sulphur Bath Establishment.- Sulphur water stronger than any in Europe. Eight European Masseurs and Masseuses. Every modern improvement.

div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.
div.p: SUBSCRIPTIONS.—Alexandria, Cairo, and the Interior of Egypt (including delivery in Alexandria or postage to subscriber's address) P.T. 231½ per annum, P.T. 116 for six months, P.T. 80 for three months. To other countries in the Postal Union P.T. 273 (£2.16s.) per annum. Six months P.T. 136½ (£1.8s.), three months P.T. 92 (£0.19s.) N.B.—Subscriptions commence from the 1st or 16th of any month.

ADVERTISEMENTS.—P.T. 4 per line. Minimum charge P.T. 20. Births, Marriages, or Deaths, not exceeding three lines, P.T. 20. Every additional line P.T. 10. Notices in news column P.T. 20 per line. Contracts entered into for standing advertisements.
SUBSCRIPTIONS and ADVERTISEMENTS are due in advance. P.O. Orders and Cheques to be made payable to the Editor and Manager, Rowland Snelling, Alexandria.
London Offices : 36, New Broad-street. B.C.
THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE can be obtained in London at our office, 36, New Broad Street, E.C., and also at Messrs. May & Williams 160, Piccadilly, W.
THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE" IS PRINTED ON PAPER MANUFACTURED AND SUPPLIED BY THE LONDON PAPER MILLS Co., LIMITED (SALES OFFICE: 27, CANNON STREET, E.C.)
Friday, February 16, 1906

div.head: The Emancipation of Egypt
div.p: Some interesting correspondence has recently appeared in our colamus on the subject of a recently published work under the above title, and if the author of this volume has rendered no other service to Egypt he has, at all events, set people pondering arew upon a political problem, the importance of which, from more than one point of view, has not abated with tha prolongation of the British Occupation. We certainly do not share-the opinion of those who would scout discussion for fear of arousing or accentaating those feelings of discontent with the present situation, which the population of Egypt are supposed to harbour. On the contrary, we hold that a candid and dispassionate examination from time to time of the status quo can have none other than a salutary effect. Disscusion, when conducted temperately and with a sincere desire on both sides to elucidate the truth, must inevitably conduce to enlightenment and in the end to a better understanding between the disputants. It is therefore of advantage that the Egyptians should be afforded opportunities of stating their alleged grievances, and that those who represent the tutelary Power should have occasion to explain the position which they take up and the policy they pursue. It is no part of our purpose to-day to seek to justify our continued presence in Egypt on the ground that withdrawal would endanger our great Indian possession, nor do we think that the doctrine of j'y suis, j'y reste is one which can recommend itselt to humane and fair minded men. Egypt's happiness and prosperity should obviously be the sole consideration, and it is from this stand-point alone that we have contemplated the existing state of affair, and contrasted it with the probable condition of the country if the author of the "Emancipation" were allowed to have his way.

With the fullest desire to give due weight to every argument advanced, and with a keen perception of the dislike that every patriot Egyptian must experience to the foreign yoke, we cannot bring ourselves to believe that the evacuation would be, at all events in the present circumstances, fraught with benefit for the Egyptians themselves. For let us ask ourselves, to what is due their ever-augmenting prosperity? It is not alone attributable to the fertility of the soil, nor to the extensive scheme of irrigation, nor to the opening up of the country by increased facilities of communication, though these, undoubtedly, are largely contributing elements. But the dominant factor in the situation is Egypt's industrial and commercial credit. Credit is the life-blood of commerce and industry, and credit is founded upon security. What is it that ensures the constant flow of foreign capital into the country, which stimulates industry, and fosters commercial enterprise? It is the knowledge that England, the world's most trusted trader and reliable merchant, is at the back of it all, and, in a sense which business men of every nationality are not slow to recognise, England stands guarantee for Egypt's financial stability. What wonder then that Sir Ernest Cassel, no mean authority on matters financial, should have volunteered the opinion that Egyptian Government securities are the soundest investment outside Corso's?

Let those who are the advocates of "emancipation" give us some reason for the faith that is within them. Let them reflect upon what would result from the adoption of their proposals. Would they willingly see credit decline, capital diminish, and foreign enterprise well righ cease, as would, assuredly happen, once the strong protective arm of England were withdrawn ? Is Egypt, unaided, in a position to cope effectively with internal disorder and to resist external attack ? If evacuation pure and simple were decided upon at this very instant or in the immediate future, where are the naval and military forces that could, in case of need, replace those of the tutelary Power? A fleet takes time to build, as America and Germany can bear effective testimony. An army is not reorganised and reinforced in a day, as English War Ministers know to their dismay. Assuming, for the sake of argument, that all this could be accomplished with a stroke of the pen. Have our Egyptian patriots counted the cost? Are they prepared to lay upon the people a burden of taxation beside which that of Germany and Italyto cite only two inetsuces—is a mere bagatelle? Egypt is much too valuable a prize to be left alone in the "scramble for Africa," and unless during the years that would be occupied in placing her naval and military forces in an efficient condition to resist attack the British would obligingly consent to remain, she would be exposed at any time to invasion by one of the Great Powers, which might result simply in a change of masters after perhaps many sanguinary encounters. Judging from the way that some European nations deal with their over-sea possessions, regarding them as mere sources for swelling revenge and utilising them as refugee for incompetent, turbulent, and dishonest officials, Egypt's last state, in the event just contemplated, might be far worse than her first.

Our patriots may probably say that neutralization is their goal, and that, by a self-denying ordinance of the Powers conjoined, the danger of invasion would be obviated. Lot as assume such an international treaty to be already in force. But how would that secure them against interneciae - feuds or domestic revolt? If such were to be the case, they might say, one of the Powers should be permitted to intervene. Precisely so. One of the Powers would, undoubtedly, intervene, but not without exacting a quid pro quo which would possibly entail hardship and oppression of which the present generation of Egyptians know only by tradition. Let us make one further and final assumption, namely, that all these gloomy though highly probable forebodings are falsified by events. What then ? Are there to be found amongst the Egyptians men ready to fill the posts of Ministers upon whose integrity and ability the nation can confidently rely ? This is a crucial point and we have been at pains to elucidate it. The present Council is, of course, out of the running, as it is 'too friendly to the English" and does not possess, therefore, the true national aspirations. But we have asked several of our best-informed and most enlightened Egyptian friends to furnish us with lists of those to whom they think might safely be entrusted the destinies of the nation. Opinions are hopelessly at variance, and with the best will in the world, we have failed to reconcile them. What is the lesson to be learned from this experiment? It is that, apart from all the other consiiderations which we have briefly indicated, the Egyptians lack that cohesion and belief in their "men of light and leading" which are the fundamental essentials of self-government.

div.head: The Holy Carpet.
div.p: The Holy Carpet will probably return to Cairo in the last 10 days of March.

div.head: Football.
div.p: A football match will be played tomorrow at the Sporting Club between Mr. Harkness' team and the Sportiog Club. Kick off 3.30.

div.head: National Bank.
div.p: We hear that the appointment of the successor of the late Sir Elwin Palmer as Governor of the National Bank will be notified, in all probability, to-morrow morning.

div.head: Found Dead.
div.p: A native carter aged fifty was found dead yesterday near Ramleh station and removed to hospital, where the post-mortem examination showed that death was due to natural causes.

div.head: Alhambra.
div.p: The artiste Marbis, who appears to be a remarkably versatile member of the manio-ball profession, will make his debut at the Alhambra next Monday in a most attractive programme.

div.head: Egyptian Heaven and Hell
div.p: Dr. E. A. Wallis Budge has completed a Work on the Egyptian Heaven and Hell in Three volumes as follows: Vol. I. The Book Am Tüst, Vol. II. The Book of Gates, and Vol III. The Egyptian Heaven and Hell.

div.head: Cairo Scientific Society.
div.p: A meeting of the society will take place on Thursday, 22nd inst., at 4.30 p.m., at the School of Medicine, when Captain H. G. Lyons will read a paper on "The Meteorological Conditions which probably affect the Nile Flood."

div.head: Land Allotment Company.
div.p: We understand that the Land Allotment Company have purchased from Count Ziginia his abadieh on the Mahmoudieh Canal, near Aufeb. The area is 660 feddans and the price L.E. 40,500. This land is not far from the company's previous purchase.

div.head: Fatal Railway Accident,
div.p: Abdou Hassau, head of the Alexandria Custom-house porters, was crossing the railway line near the coal quay yesterday, when he was run over by a passing train and seriously injured. He was removed to hospital for prompt medical treatment but half-an-hour afterwards he succumbed to his injuries.

div.head: The Cab Strike.
div.p: A meeting was held yesterday afternoon of the special committee which has been nominated to deal with the grievances of the Alexandria cabmen. It was decided to recommend the adoption of a new cab tariff, which is a slight increase on the present fares for the city and a one-third increase on those in vogue in Ramleh. This tariff is to be submitted to an extraordinary meeting of the Municipal Commission.

div.head: Kippin Yusen Kaisha.
div.p: The service of these Japanese passenger steamers, interrupted during the war, has been renewed and the steamer Igo Maru, one of the latest additions to the fleet, will shortly arrive at Suez en route for England. This steamer will be the pioneer of the resumed service of the company between London, the Straits, China, and Japan. It is intended that the Igo Maru shall leave London about the end of April, and in June the Nippon Yusen Kaisha's regular service will be definitely recommenced

div.head: Suez Canal Profits.
div.p: When Lord Beaconsfield arranged the bargain with Ismail Pachs, the Extravagant, for the purchase of the latter's share of the Suez Canal, many eminent Radicals denounced the transaction as not only risky but as opposed to all righteousness. But, nowadays, the screaming virtue of that political cult prefers to keep silence, meanwhile pocketing the profits from the greatest international deal of a commercial character that has ever occurred. In the annual report of the Liverpool Stamship Owners' Association it is stated that since the Khedive's shares passed into British ownership the aggregate money yield has amounted to nine and a half millions sterling. As the purchase price was no more than four millions, the net profit up to the end of last year works out at five and a half millions. But the golden stream has only been flowing into the English Treasury, since the end of 1899; up to that date all receipts were used to pay interest charges on the four millions borrowed to carry out the bargain and to liquidate the capital sum. It was not, therefore, until the beginning of 1900 that John Bull came into the nice little addition to his income placed at his service by the great Conservative statesman. During the six years that have subsequently passed the average annual profit has amounted to nearly a million sterling, while the original outlay has been recouped without taking a single farthing out of the British taxpayer's purse.

div.head: EDEN PALACE HOTEL,
div.p: CAIRO
NOTED FOR ITS EXCELLENT CUISINE.
ELECTRIC LIGHT. LIFT.
Special terms for officers of the Army of Occupation and Government Officials. 26-11-90

div.head: Moeris Hotel,
div.p: on Lake Moeris.
First Class Encampment
In connection with the Karoon Hotel Fayoum.
For particulars apply Mr. TASCO, Fayoum.

div.head: SPEECH BY PREMIER. NO SURPRISES IN KING'S SPEECH.
div.p: Sir H. Campbell-Bannerman, speaking at the National Liberal Club, delivered a speech which was full of aptly expressed sentences. He said that there would be no surprises in the King's Speech. The Premier also stated that the result of the general election was indicative of a revolt and an uprising against the doctrine, practice, and methods of the late Government, which were abhorrent to the nation. He referred to the present disunited condition of tbe Opposition.

div.head: MR. BALFOUR AND FISCAL REFORM.
div.p: In the correspondence which has passed between Mr. Balfour and Mr, Chamberlain, Mr. Balfour agrees with the latter that fiscal reform must be the first constructive work of the Unionist Party. The fact that the late Premier, while repudiating Protection, agrees that a small duty on foreign corn and a moderate general tariff on manufactured goods would secure more equal terms in competition, and bring about closer commercial union with the colonies, has brought Mr. Chamberlain into line with him.
It is authoritatively stated that the Duke of Levonshire is attending the meeting of the Unionist party at Lansdowne House to-day.

div.head: EDITORSHIP OF "PUNCH."
div.p: Sir F. C. Burnand has retired from the editorship of "Punch," and is succeeded by Mr. Owen Seaman, the assistant editor.

div.head: LEGISLATIVE COUNCIL.
div.p: The Legislative Council met yesterday and took cognisance of a letter addressed to it by the Government in which the Government expressed its approbation of the Council's suggestion that money grants up to the value of five feddans should be given to Bedouin chiefs who owned no land. The Ministry of the Interior will distribute these grants to the most deserving applicants from among those cbiefs who hold no landed property.

div.head: OUR ABYSSINIAN VISITORS.
div.p: General Machacha and the members of the Abyssibian Mission will leave Alexandria for Jerusalem in all probability tomorrow or the day after. A "Gazette" representative interviewed the General this morning through an interpreter as he does not speak Arabic well, and he stated that he hopes that he will recover the £25,000 taken from him at Constantinople on his arrival at Jerusalem He declared that the money had been taken from him on board the steamer at the moment of embarking, by a man of Hungarian origin, who had been in his service for two years. This man, said the General, had been induced to seize the money by an Abyssinian ecclesiastic at Jerusalem. For some time past this dignity had been on bad terms with the General, who expressed vehement dislike for him. The money has been sent to Jerusalem and the General will take measures to have the sum restored to him.

div.head: MUNICIPAL ELECTIONS.
div.p: The election of three members of the Municipal Conmission belonging to the category of Importers will take place at the offices of the Importers' Association, 20, Sesostris-street, on Monday, 26th int from 9.30 a.m. to 4.00 p.m The ballot will eventually take place on Wednesday, 28th inst., at the same hours.
The list of importing, merchants who are allowed to vote is posted up at the Governors rat, the Municipality, the Khediviel Bourse, and the Association's office.

div.head: ARABIC AT CAMBRIDGE.
div.p: The special Board for Oriental studies at the University of Cambridge has presented a report, which contains recommendations that should be of great service to Egyptians and other Arabic-speaking people desires of entering at that University. The Board recommend:
1. That natives of Asis and Africa not of - European parentage be permitted to offer ar abstitutes for Greek and Latin in the Previous Examination :
(2) English for one language.
(b) Either Arabic, Chinese, or Sanskrit for the other.
2. That an examination in Arabic, Chinese and Sanskrit be held (when required) in the Previous Examination, which takes place at the end of the Michaelmas Term.
3. That no student be allowed to offer himself as a candidate for this examination after the end of his third term of residence.
4. That no stadent who has passed in Arabic, Chinese, or Sanskrit in the Previous

Examination be allowed to offer himself as a candidate for the Oriental Language Tipes. These recommendations are permissive, and it will still be posible for any students belonging to these classes to show their acquaintance with Western literature and methods, if they should desire to do so, by passing the Previous Examination as at present constituted.

div.head: The Frontier Incident
div.p: IS SINAI EGYPTIAN ?
INCIDENT WITH TURKISH TROOPS.

The "Lewa" states that the Turkish occupation of Tabah, is based on the belief that the Sinai is in no sense a part of Egypt but a territory temporarily confided to Egyptian care. If this be so, the outlook is not altogether pleasant, but we imagine that the confusion between Tabah and Dabah is far more likely to have caused the incident.

Our contemporary also states that Turkish troops are close to Keaat-en-Nakhl, but have not occupied the port. It adds that Mr. F. J Bramley and 25 soldiers landed near Tabah from the Nour-el-Bahr and met the Turkish commandant, who refared to retire, whereupon the Egyptians withdrew.

div.head: THE BAHR-EL-GHAZAL.
div.p: The Brussels correspondent of the "Times" states that an anthoritative contradiction is given to the report publisbed in the London Press about trouble between Egyptian and Congo troops in Bahr el Ghazal. According to the latest news all is quiet in that region. It is pointed out that Article 12 of the Berlin Act provides for arbitration in any dispute arising in the basin of the Congo, a course which the Brussels Administration has more than once advocated.

div.head: BAD WEATHER AT SUEZ.
div.p: (FROM OUR CORRESPONDENT)
Suez, Thursday.

A southerly gale raged at Suez all last night and only abated this morning. Owing to the gale and fog in the canal, all steamers had to tie up,and most of them anchored for the night at Ismailia, only proceeding at 8 o'clock this morning, when the weather was somewhat clearer. Among the detained vessels was the P. & O. mail steamer Marmora, which only reached Suez this afternoon, being 12 hours late.
The weather, although not quite settled yet, seems to be clearing up.
Steamers coming up from the south report thick weather in the Suez Golf, on account of which they had to slow down.

div.head: FREEMASONRY IN EGYPT.
div.p: The Zetland Lodge (No. 116 F. E. C.) held a must successful installation meeting on Tuesday last. This ceremony was attended by the Deputy District Grand Master, Dr. Keatinge, and several other officers of the District Grand Lodge of Egypt and the Sudan. There were also many visitors from other lodges. Worshipful Brother Walter F. Sarjeaut, the retiring Master, performed the ceremony of installation of Brother Irvine in a most able manner.

Afterwards & banqaet was held in the ballroom of the New Khedivial Hotel. The fare provided was excellent and the greatest cordially prevailed. The usual Masonic toasts were given, interspersed by a charming selection of music by d'Ambra's Band. Songs and other entertaining features were given during the evening.

div.head: CONCERT AT THE SAVOY HOTEL.
div.p: He is a brave man who follows on the footsteps of Signor Serato, but Mr. Kaufman, young as he is, acquitted himself admirably yesterday afternoon when he and his aunt, Mrs. Amster, gave one of the many delightful concerts of the Cairo season. It is unfair to compare Mr. Kaufman's playing with that of Signor Serato, who has already won the hearts of his hearers, but Mr. Kaufman has very much in his favour and will cortainly make a name for himself. Perhaps it was a natural diffidence that made his Sonata by Griega somewhat colourless performance, the first movement perceptibly dragging his second item. Bruch's second concert, was very much more spontaneous and full of feeling, and his final numbers were delightful in their purity tone and fineness of expression. His rendering of that delicate fantasy of Bazzini's, La Ronde des Lutins, with its subtle intervals and difficult bowing, was above criticism. In response to the insistence of the audience Mr. Kaufman gave as an encore Pierne's Seranado, which he played with a mute, and which was received with every mark of satisfaction. His technique is indeed excellent, and his tone
sure, if sometimes lacking in force, but he possesses a fine feeling and a very refined artistic sense.

Mrs. Amster, the beautiful and talented wife of Dr. Amster, received a very warm welcome from her many friends and admirers, and her songs by Brahma, Schumann, and Schubert were duly appreciated. She has a beautifully sympathetic and flexible voice and sings with much delicacy and intelligence. In her two last songs by Horwitz she was accompanied by the composer, who is a son-in-law of Heller's.
Mme, Archibald and Mr. Schweitzer acted as accompaniats and performed their allotted parts in a most sympathetic and able manner.

There will be another concert at the Savoy Hotel on Sunday evening, when Frau Professor Schear Brodmann, of Wiesbaden, and Mr. Buop Giesen, of Dresden wll appear, from Bro'mann is a very roted operatic singer in Vienna and her performances have received frequent expressions of approval from the Emperor William. Mr. Giessen is also well known on account of his fine tenorr voice.

div.head: The Gordon College
div.p: Higher Technical School
DESCRIPTION OF THE SYLLABUS.

The Higher Technical Sobool was formed and its courses were arranged on the lines suggested. It was opened in October, 1905, and fifteen students presented themselves-seven from the Gordon College Sobool, seven from Omdurman, and one from the Gamalieh School, Cairo. They are divided into two sections or sides, seven studying surveying in a two years' and eight engineering in a four years' course. At present it would be premature to give details of the syllabus as though it were definitely fixed. The school is still in an experimental stage, and at the age of five months it is hard even for parents to prophesy how a child will develop. Meantime the instructors hope to be able to follow a course that will continne the boy's general education while adding to it a definite and sound technical training. Here is the syllabus as proposed for the first year. In general subjects, the English, the translation and the Arabic composition will be simply a continuation of the work done in the higher primary schools. Geography and mathematics, on the other hand, will now be taught for the first time in English. The geography will consist partly of the recapitulation of the general geography already learnt with a special reference to the dominions of the British Empire, and partly of a more detailed treatment of the Nile Valley from fresh points of view, such as the engineer's, the trader's, and the agriculturalist's.
The mathematics tanght will be a repetition and extension in English of the arithmetic and geometry previously learnt in Arabic, and in addition to these the elements of algebra and trigonometry.
Technical Subjects.

a) SURVEYORS. - The surveyer's work will be partly practical, partly theoretical. The practical field work includes practice in chain- surveying, angular surveying, and levelling, while trigonometrical surveying will be described. The field implements and instruments used are ranging rods and pickets, chains and arrows, optical square and cross staff, tape, prismatic compass, plane table, and Cooke's level. The office work will consist of construction of plain and diagonal scales, use and selection of plotting and offset scales, plotting to scale from survey and level field notes, computation of "traverse sheet" of co-ordinates, taking out areas by triangles and trapeziums, use of planimeter, preparation of tracing and blue-prints.

b) ENGINEERS.—The engineers' work, like the surveyor's, is both practical and theoretic, and as the subject is much wider, the courses will be more extended and will probably last longer. In the first year an attempt will be made to give the students a superficial acquaintance with a number of branches which will be only treated fully in subsequent years. Their work falls into three main divisions.
Manual Training.
Each boy will spend about eight hours a week in one of the instructional workshops, learning the handicrafts of carpentering, fitting, smithing and engine-driving, passing half a year in each shop.
Mechanical Drawing.
Boys will be taught the use of instruments, of tracing paper and cloth, colouring and mounting drawings, working and detail drawings the reproduction of drawings by sun photo-printing.
Lectures

These will consist during the first year of a series of courses illustrated whenever possible by practical demonstration on the elements of mensuration of areas, solids, etc. hydraulics, statics, building and engineering materials, constructional work, tools and implements. In later years these courses will be expanded and supplemented by proper testing operations in the laboratory. Students will be taught further how to write reports, draw contracts, and check work done.

Our readers can form an opinion of the value of the training thus given. It seems practical enough, and will, perhaps, be of value not for the Sodan only. Technical education requires development in Egypt, and when that development comes its organisers will not do amiss to take a leaf from the Sudan educational book.
To be continued

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The E'lerman S.S. Belgravian sailed from Malta last night and is due here on Monday morning with general cargo.
The S.S. Roman Prince, from London, with passengers and general cargo, left Malta yesterday, and is due at Alexandria on Monday.

div.head: ARISTON AERATED WATERS
div.p: Guaranteed Distilled.
ALEXANDRIA: 7 Rue de la Poste.
CAIRO opposite the Tramways Co. Works, Sharia Sahal, Kasr-el-Nil

div.head: Isherwood's Cairo Cigarettes.
div.p: The reputation which these Cigarettes have gained in the past, stands unrivalled today, because it is well-known that constant care and attention is devoted to supplying treally first-class Cigarettes only.
Between the Bristish Consulate and Turf Club.

div.head: The Native Press
div.p: Education In Egypt
LATE MUFTI'S "POLITICAL WILL."

"Al Lewa" says :-Mr. de Guerville allowed, himself to publish in his book "New Egypt" the opinions of Sheikh Mohamed Abdou, in regard to the lack of public instruction in Egypt, because, thinks the author, the late Mufti's statement, being a part of his political will, must be declared after his death. No doubt the English would have felt displeased with the late Sheikh's opinion, which shows how little cared for education is in Egypt. But they must consider, if they are a just people, that no native of this country can be pleased with the backwardness of Egypt and the loss of its authority. In spite of England's attempts to support its purposes in Egypt by concealing the real facts and buying the unscrupulous writers' pens, the reality, obvious as it looks, cannot be suppressed and the voice of Egypt will never cease to declare its rights.
After quoting the late Mufti's statement, "Al Lewa" concludes as follows:-
"Now what do the occupants think of Sheikh Mohamed Abdou's declaration ? Was he also one of those who opposed the English Occupation and severely criticised its policy, as they say?"
The Red Sea and England.

Mustapha Pacha Kamel makes the following remarks in "Al Lewa '' :--The most important scheme of the British Government is to detach Arabia from the Turkish Empire and place its Government in the hands of an Arabian Caliph, whom it would employ for its own ends. British statesmen are doing their utmost in this direction, but their efforts have been unsuccessful. The Ottoman Power has lately suppressed the Yemen rebellion, and the Hedjaz Railway will completely join the Turkish capital with the sacred towns, adding considerable force to the Ottoman Government, albeit, Port Sudan which is the first English harbour in the Red Sea, now forms an important naval station for the British forces before Jeddah. Therefore the railways, though necessary and vital for the Ottoman Empire, will not do without a real navy- powerful fleet to defend the Ottoman coasts and secure the Red Sea as an Ottoman lake and not leave it to be converted into an English one. It is a very sad thing to see England threatening Turkey and Islam by means of Egypt and its money, while the Egyptian Ministry slumbers.

div.head: LONG CREDITS IN EGYPT.
div.p: The following statement on the subject of credits in Egypt appears in the "Manchester Guardian."

A Lancashire manufacturer who has tried the experiment of direct trading with Egypt sends us a copy of the Monthly Journal of the British Chamber of Commerce of Egypt, an article in which confirms his experience. Egypt, it is agreed, is a country of long credits, the main causes being (1) that apart from home consumption the cultivator produces only one selling crop per annum of any value -usually cotton; (2) the ingrained habit of the native not to honour his bills on the due date, and (3) the land-hunger which is so strongly developed in the fellaheen. As the cultivator only handles ready money in any quantity at one period of the year, he makes the retailer wait for the account, who in his turn keeps the merchant waiting. But it is most difficult for the British trader to understand the lightness with which the Arab dishonours his acceptances. He regards those rather as the acknowledgments of his debts than as positive obligations to pay them, and his keeness to acquire land urges him to take advantags of any suitable opportunity even at the expense of his credit. The great competition of the last for years has mude very easy torms for the natives, and even when a bill is renewed it is very difficult to include interest, one reason being the religious objection of the Arab to its payment. On the whole, then, it appears that unless a manufacturer can see his way to profits sufficiently good to counterbalance the various financial disadvantages he had better leave Egyptian trade to those who understand it. There seems to be no reason, however, why his representatives, with the necessary experience, should not understand it as well as anyone else.

div.head:
Passenger List
DEPARTURES.
div.p: Per S.S. Nilo of the Florio-Rubattino Co., sailed for Venice:
Rev. Vine Ball and 14 third class passengers
Per S.S. Perseo of the Florio Rubattino Co., sailed for Genoa yesterday :

MM. De Carlier and Gaiffier, M. Ott P. Spotte, Mr. and Mrs. E. A. Hayes, M. Gau and family, M. Jacques, M. Cottoy, Mr. and Mrs. Provost, Mr. Ellen Emery, M. Hersonn, Mr. and Mrs. Ugo Ojetti, M. A. Pinto, Mr. and Mrs. Magg Kade, Mr. and Mrs. S. Ristabuer, Mr. D. Gronsi, Mr. Blach, H. H. Prince Mohamed Aly Halim, Mr. A. Hagey, Mr. and Mrs. G. Davanso, Mr. Laisa Cbieri, and child.

div.head: CARLTON HOTEL
div.p: Bulkeley (near Alexandria.)
Ramleh's Fashionable Hotel.
Patronized by the Elite.
Full Pension P.T. 50 a day. Visitors fron Cairo alight at Sidi-Gaber Station.
G. AQUILINA, Proprieter.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: H. H. Prince Mobamed Aly Halim left for Europe yesterday by the S. S. Perseo.
Don Carlos and the Duchess of Madrid are back from their trip to the Holy Land and are now staying again at Shepheard's.
Lord and Lady Londesborough have not postponed but entirely onnoelled their trip to Egypt owing to the illness of the Earl.

A very pleasant "At Home" was given by Mr. Grew, of the American Agency, yesterday. Mr. Storer, the American Ambassador in Vienna, who is now staying at Cairo, and Lady Cromer were prosent at the function, with many well-known members of Cairo Society.
We regret to announce the death of Countess Howe, wife of Earl Howe and daughter of the seventh Duke of Marlborough. She died on Friday last at Lord Howe's residence in Curzon-street.

H. H. the Khedive has been pleased to confer the rank of Lewa (rear-admiral) on Captain Herbert J. Gedge, R. N., Deputy Director-General of Ports and Lighthouses. This rank carries with it the title of Pacha.
Mr. A. Luzzatto, general manager of the Bank of Egypt, has returned to Alexandria from his tour of inspection in Upper Egypt and Khartoum.

The new editor of "Punch" Mr. Owen Seaman, M.A., who was born in 1861, joined the staff of "Punch" in the year 1897, but had previously contributed to its colomns since 1894, when be also wrote for the "National Observer" (O.S.) and for the "World" under the nom-de-plume of "Nautious." He received his education in Shrewsbury, where he was captain of the school in 1880, and at Clare College, Cambridge. He is a University Porson Prizeman and secured first class in Classical Tripos in 1883. Before taking to journalism he was master at Rossall School and subsequently, professor of literature at Durham College of Science, Newcastle-on-Tyne.

Mrs. and Miss Crofton, who aro staying at the Ghezireh Palace Hotel, gave a delightfal dance there on Wednesday night. Unluckily a severe sandstorm was spreading havoc over Cairo that evening, and many of those invited were not able to attend. But among those present were noticed Lady and Miss Lampson, Dr. and Mrs. Armstrong, Miss ffrench, Lady and Miss Hemming, and a goodly contingent of the officers of the various regiments stationed in the neighbourhood. Dancing was continued with much zest till a late hour in the ballroom, and an excellent supper was enjoyed in the adjoining dining-room.
